, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 115%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">bhinnamatam ekikrutva<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 115%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">sanghachhemahi samvademahi (2)</span></i></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-t4TS3AO7Mas/V-OgpS7R1gI/AAAAAAABMBI/liSTzofQKX8dNGrAsY_NfmsESrvUIDw1ACLcB/s1600/Photo0141.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-t4TS3AO7Mas/V-OgpS7R1gI/AAAAAAABMBI/liSTzofQKX8dNGrAsY_NfmsESrvUIDw1ACLcB/s400/Photo0141.jpg\" width=\"261\" /></a></div>\n<br />\nCAPT AJIT VADAKAYIL<br />\n..</div>\n", "author": {"id": "14410812789424637654", "displayName": "Capt. Ajit Vadakayil", "url": "https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654", "image": {"url": "//4.bp.blogspot.com/-QSnd-Z8F7Kc/XFtPudWdwlI/AAAAAAABfq4/vxrkFOO7Iu8Mf6-OaPgw6FPpRDSmMgLdgCK4BGAYYCw/s35/capt%25252BajitC%25252Bvadakayil.JPG"}}, "replies": {"totalItems": "107", "selfLink": "https://www.googleapis.com/blogger/v3/blogs/3564735312144269387/posts/8217034722958014676/comments"}}, {"kind": "blogger#post", "id": "435980489874829046", "blog": {"id": "3564735312144269387"}, "published": "2016-09-20T13:41:00+05:30", "updated": "2017-12-29T05:51:15+05:30", "etag": "\"iHf3yWDE_geBgZ8U7rgZ_xuTeAQ/dGltZXN0YW1wOiAxNTE0NTA2ODc1MTc0Cm9mZnNldDogMTk4MDAwMDAK\"", "url": "http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of_20.html", "selfLink": "https://www.googleapis.com/blogger/v3/blogs/3564735312144269387/posts/435980489874829046", "title": "MARATHON RUNNING , SECRETS OF ELECTROLYTES AND PERSONALISED DRINKS , part 4 \u2013 CAPT AJIT VADAKAYIL", "content": "<div dir=\"ltr\" style=\"text-align: left;\" trbidi=\"on\">\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>THIS POST IS CONTINUED FROM PART 3 , BELOW--</b></span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of_17.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of_17.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Your body produces\nlactic acid, or lactate, in the absence of enough oxygen to convert glucose to\nenergy. As your level of intensity increases, so do your levels of lactic acid.\nYour body produces lactate when oxygen levels are low, in order to allow for\nthe breakdown of glucose for energy.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Your body normally receives fuel through a\nprocess known as glycolysis, which turns glucose into a substance known as\npyruvate, and then, when sufficient oxygen is available, delivers it through\naerobic pathways as energy. However, when oxygen levels are depleted, as often\noccurs during periods of strenuous exercise or infectious disease, your body\nconverts pyruvate to lactate to facilitate glucose breakdown.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Lactic acidosis\nis a condition that occurs when too much lactic acid builds up in your blood at\na rate that is faster than it is used to. This condition contributes symptoms\nof weakness, possibly hampering athletic performance. Lactic threshold is\ndetermined by blood testing and has been used to determine the optimal training\nregime to maximize speed while minimizing muscle fatigue.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is a difference\nbetween rest and recovery\u2014though both are crucial in enhancing performance. Rest\nis generally categorized as sleep and time spent not training or exercising.\nRecovery, on the other hand, refers to techniques and actions taken to maximize\nyour body\u2019s repair. And this doesn\u2019t just mean muscle repair. Recovery involves\nchemical and hormonal balance, nervous system repair, mental state and more.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Active recovery (AR)\nfocuses on completing an exercise at a low intensity, but high enough to\nincrease blood flow and enhance the clearance of enzymes responsible for muscle\ndamage and residual fatigue. Therefore AR plays a huge role in minimizing the\nsymptoms of DOMS (delayed onset muscle soreness). Whether its swimming,\ncycling, kayaking, running, etc., make sure you are doing the activity at\n60-70% effort\u2014an easy, restorative pace.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/_qQrRpLdqLc/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/_qQrRpLdqLc?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Protein is most\nimportant after a marathon run for the repair of muscle tissue to aid in the\nrecovery of muscle cells.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As sore as you are it\u2019s\nimportant to not take excessive amount of time away from the gym. You should\nstill be lifting but at lower intensities, it can surely improve recovery by\npromoting blood circulation back into working muscles &amp; allowing for waste\nproducts to disperse (metabolites). This is active recovery.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">DOMS occurs mostly\nafter unfamiliar exercise, which causes microtrauma to the muscle fibres. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On our honeymoon me and my wife went horse\nriding the whole day though private estates at Ooty. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The next day both of us\nwere walking with our legs apart in such&nbsp;\na funny way ( sore inner thigh muscles), the people in the hotel wondered\nwho RAPED whom. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">TEE HEEEEEE !<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Minimum hours a person\nneeds to be sleeping per night should range between 7 to 9 hours with REM\nsleep.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>Plyometrics</b></span></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"> is a\nstrength-building, high-intensity form of exercise that requires almost no\nequipment. It can also be done from anywhere, gym or living room. Because it\u2019s\na quick and intense way to work your lower body.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plyometrics workouts\nare intense. If you want to, you can pretty much dedicate an entire training\nsession to plyo alone. It\u2019s great for both muscle building and fat burning, so\nyou can get a lot out of plyo sets in less time than a typical cardio or\nstrength workout. Each plyo \u201cset\u201d is made up of only a few reps.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The goal is to\nperform the moves as quickly and \u201cexplosively\u201d as possible. Keep your heart\nrate up by giving yourself a 90 second break between sets. Go until you can\nreally feel it in your legs and butt \u2013 but try not to push too far beyond that.\nDon\u2019t hurt yourself.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plyometrics focuses on\nlearning to move from a muscle extension to a contraction in a rapid or\n\"explosive\" manner, such as in specialized repeated jumping.\nPlyometrics are primarily used by athletes, especially martial artists,\nsprinters and high jumpers, to improve performance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Olympic athletes use\nplyometrics training to improve muscular strength and jumping abilities which\ntherefore increases their power. There are varying levels of intensity to\nplyometrics.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Another benefit of plyometrics are that you can vary your level of\nintensity which means anyone looking to improve strength and jumping training\ncan be involved regardless of fitness. With there being so many exercises this\nmeans you are less likely to get burned out and have a wide range of exercises\nto choose from.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Another good reason with so many exercises being available are\nthat you can find exercises that don\u2019t require the use of any equipment. It\nalso increases muscular strength and endurance, also increases metabolic rate\nwhich increases weight loss and heart rate<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/N2YETWV1RsM/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/N2YETWV1RsM?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Klatt test was\ndesigned to effectively highlight possible muscular imbalances at the knee,\nhip, pelvis and lower back. Only if you pass this LITMUS test can you go for\nPlyometrics.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/igS1nA4_Rz8/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/igS1nA4_Rz8?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_26M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of_20.html?showComment=1474382442319#c786433842587050476\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">September 20, 2016 at 8:10 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_26MC\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nSOME ONE ASKED ME<br />\n<br />\nHOW CAN YOUR SAY THAT SIMONE BILES IS TAKING DRUGS<br />\n<br />\nWELL THAT IS BECAUSE ONLY DRUGS CAN EXPLAIN HER MIGHTY \"<b><span style=\"color: red;\">REACTIVE STRENGTH INDEX</span></b> \"<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-vfZpxEeSQH0/V-FKlstkZfI/AAAAAAABL_g/rDWlVuAhuS8Omjy80UJZAijQrzsoKOrKQCLcB/s1600/doewnload.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"238\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-vfZpxEeSQH0/V-FKlstkZfI/AAAAAAABL_g/rDWlVuAhuS8Omjy80UJZAijQrzsoKOrKQCLcB/s400/doewnload.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Consumption of a\ncarbohydrate gel before and during an event significantly improves the\nendurance capacity of marathon athletes, but had little beneficial effect on\nshort sprint performance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbohydrates are the\nmost important nutrient for marathon athletes to consume when preparing for a marathon.\nBecause the skeletal muscles are fuelled mainly by glucose derived from\ncarbohydrates, it is important to adequately build up muscle stores of glycogen\nto promote a decrease in fatigue during the race.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The day before the\nevent is the most crucial time period to prepare the body for the marathon\nahead. The day directly before the event is the day where carbohydrate intake\nis extremely important to &nbsp;revent the\n\u201chitting the wall\u201d sensation that often happens and is the result of\noverwhelming fatigue. This strategy is known as carbohydrate loading. For OP\nJaisha this translates to kanjee ( rice gruel) .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbohydrate loading is\nthe super compensating of muscle glycogen stores in preparation for prolonged\nexercise. Each gram of carbohydrate provides four calories of energy for the\nathlete.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Effective carbohydrate\nloading consists of 10 grams of carbohydrates per kilogram of body weight.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbohydrate loading\nhas not been associated with an increase in overall running speed, but instead,\nwith an increased ability to maintain running pace throughout the event.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Carbohydrate loading\nhelps prolong glucose depletion leaving the marathon runner energized for a longer\nperiod of time. . The menstrual status of females also effects glycogen storage\nwith greater </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">storage occurring during\nthe luteal phase rather than the follicular phase. The coach of a female runner\nmust be privy to her menstrual dates.</span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Consuming carbohydrates\nwill replenish glucose levels in the skeletal muscles which will help prolong the\nonset of fatigue, causing an improvement of exercise performance by allowing\nthe runner to maintain their running pace longer.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">After the marathon, the\nathlete must replenish the muscles and their glycogen stores because the\nglycogen levels were extremely depleted during the marathon to fuel the body\u2019s extreme\nenergy needs. Resting muscle glycogen stores range from 500 to 600 mmol/kg body\nweight and will decrease greatly &nbsp;during prolonged\nendurance exercise.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The consumption of 1.2\ngrams of carbohydrates per kilogram of body weight is the ideal amount of carbohydrates\nto consume after an endurance event.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The consumption of\nprotein at a ratio of 1:3 with carbohydrates post exercise increases the\nmuscle\u2019s ability to replenish glycogen stores.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In other words, the consumption\nof small amounts of protein, 0.4 grams per kilogram of body weight, in combination\nwith carbohydrates is the ideal post workout nutrition.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Post exercise muscle\nglycogen synthesis occurs in two different phases. The first phase of glycogen\nsynthesis, is independent of circulating&nbsp;\ninsulin and lasts about 30-60 minutes after the completion of exercise. &nbsp;During this phase, glycogen synthesis rates\nare high (30-45 mmol per kilogram), but decrease rapidly when no carbohydrates\nare ingested.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/MQs4SqirpzY/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/MQs4SqirpzY?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because carbohydrates\nare the skeletal muscles\u2019 main source of fuel, glycogen stores in the muscles\nmust always be at adequate levels to provide the athlete with the needed energy\nto run the 42 km miles of a marathon.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-KgTIawUEXQU/V-ImkkDMoHI/AAAAAAABL_4/zRmGirl-vYMsnSer3zGnutW4huyYlnrOQCLcB/s1600/dpigs.PNG\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"478\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-KgTIawUEXQU/V-ImkkDMoHI/AAAAAAABL_4/zRmGirl-vYMsnSer3zGnutW4huyYlnrOQCLcB/s640/dpigs.PNG\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Carbohydrate loading is\nonly effective for endurance events lasting longer than 90 minutes, such as\nmarathons, ultra marathons, and triathlons.</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During intense,\ncontinuous endurance exercise, your muscles will become depleted of glycogen\nafter about 90 minutes.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-Qb7JJjHFeis/V-ImP7R1wOI/AAAAAAABL_0/X1XOHd1qgXE_qNcapT2T2nrmWlZdGd-kQCLcB/s1600/ewvolutionofthemarathon%2Bcopy.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"414\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-Qb7JJjHFeis/V-ImP7R1wOI/AAAAAAABL_0/X1XOHd1qgXE_qNcapT2T2nrmWlZdGd-kQCLcB/s640/ewvolutionofthemarathon%2Bcopy.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">Below: OP Jaisha was deprived off her regular diet of rice and fish curry at Rio</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ujQleAosvEY/V-Il6tEBT6I/AAAAAAABL_w/hBNKxpTZXq8XKIjbcrne-H-hnSaK6sYEgCLcB/s1600/carbohydrate-loading-anxxd-insulin-supplementation-in-sport-4-638.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ujQleAosvEY/V-Il6tEBT6I/AAAAAAABL_w/hBNKxpTZXq8XKIjbcrne-H-hnSaK6sYEgCLcB/s640/carbohydrate-loading-anxxd-insulin-supplementation-in-sport-4-638.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carb loading is meant\nto store extra glycogen that your muscles can tap into once the normal stores\nare used up.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbohydrate loading is\nnot useful for events like a 5 km runs since &nbsp;the running effort will not be long enough to\ncompletely deplete muscle glycogen stores.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/-zNG1a4OMJk/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/-zNG1a4OMJk?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Glycogen is important\nfor any endurance event, but it is in the marathon where it is of utmost\nimportance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Unlike refuelling a\ncar, the timing of your carbohydrate intake is vital, due to the role of\nenzymes in the body.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Immediately after\nexercise, the body secretes large amounts of an enzyme called glycogenase,\nmaking the muscles and liver highly receptive to absorbing and storing\ncarbohydrate. The increased level of glycogenase in the blood is raised for\nabout two hours, with this time frame being the optimum window for the lost\ncarbohydrate stores to be replaced.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If insufficient\ncarbohydrate is eaten and the timing is wrong, performance can be severely\ncompromised in subsequent training runs often leaving runners confused as to\nwhy they feel so tired</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-9qNEUJmYTKk/V-IqckV2FvI/AAAAAAABMAA/VWhHSEve6tgkaUnztTV_wqJEAvOPgOkSwCLcB/s1600/muscrre4.gif\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"278\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-9qNEUJmYTKk/V-IqckV2FvI/AAAAAAABMAA/VWhHSEve6tgkaUnztTV_wqJEAvOPgOkSwCLcB/s400/muscrre4.gif\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">After you consume foods\nand drinks containing carbohydrates, they are broken down into smaller\nmolecules, like sugars, in your gut. Through a series of chemical reactions,\nthe body\u2019s cells convert sugars into an energy currency called ATP, which\npowers physical activity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b>MALLESHWARI WOULD HAVE\nWON A GOLD MEDAL AT THE OLYMPICS ( SHE GOT BRONZE ) IF HER FOREIGN COACH HAD\nNOT SABOTAGED HER<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">YOU HAVE READ THIS POST\nSO FAR-- ALL THOSE WHO THINK THAT OP JAISHAs FOREIGN COACH DID NOT SABOTAGE HER\nRUN, RAISE YOUR HANDS . .</b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">TINTU LUKA SHOULD KNOW\nTHIS.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">FIRST OF ALL DON\u2019T OSCILLATE\nOR ROTATE YOUR HEAD WHEN RUNNING-- LIKE AN IDIOT . &nbsp; &nbsp;HOLD HEAD STEADY.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/z-KLr64EyDM/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/z-KLr64EyDM?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">RUNNING INVOLVED MIND\nGAMES.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">THERE IS NOTHING AS\nEXHILARATING AS OVERTAKING OTHERS WHEN YOU NEAR THE FINISH LINE.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">THERE IS NOTHING AS\nDEMORALIZING AS OTHERS OVERTAKING YOU WHEN YOU NEAR THE FINISH LINE.&nbsp; &nbsp; YOU TEND TO TANK THE RACE ..&nbsp;</span></b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"color: red;\">BRAIN PRODUCES WONDER\nPOWER BOOSTING CHEMICALS WHEN YOU EXHILARATE.</span></b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">You can entertain\nyourself and keep your pace in the final 10K of the race by going\n\"fishing\". Cast your invisible fishing line and hook a runner ahead\nof you who went out too fast. Reel them in slowly, staying in the Orange Zone,\nand focus on the next person. There's nothing more empowering than passing\npeople (nicely) in the second half of a race. It keeps your mind mentally\nactivated, focused, and allows you to run stronger than you could ever imagine.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Marathon runner must\nwear a large LCD digital watch . Do your very best to run the first mile at\nexactly your goal pace time. Don't run slower to \"save energy\" for\nthe final miles, because it's very unlikely that you will be able to make up\ntime at that point, and don't run faster to \"put time in the bank,\"\nas this usually results in a precipitous decline in pace after 20 miles.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The marathon course\nmust be known to the coach.&nbsp; For example,\nalmost the entire first half of the Boston Marathon is downhill, while the\nsecond half is not. Therefore you should plan to run the first half at a pace\nthat's slightly faster than your target pace for the whole event.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By contrast,\nthe San Francisco Marathon is much hillier in the first half than in the\nsecond, so a planned negative split is definitely the way to go in this event. &nbsp;For uphill run use a thread mill with tilt mechanism\nfor strengthening calf muscles.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Double layered socks\nare a must-have for marathon &nbsp;runners\nitem. They really work in helping to prevent the dreaded blisters.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Below: Earthing founder ? Sorry this is part of 6200 year old Ayurveda.</span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/8KxsaZxXEZ0/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/8KxsaZxXEZ0?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">After a long run, sit\non wet grass so that your calves and feet absorb free electrons from the earth.\n.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/1qSAZXjOo9g/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/1qSAZXjOo9g?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<b><span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\">YOGA MUST BE DONE WITH YOUR BODY EARTHED</span></b><br />\n<b><span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\">WHEN YOU MEDITATE YOUR BODY MUST BE INSULATED&nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\">In cold windy weather men and women runners must avoid NIPPLE CHAFING . Put some virgin coconut oil . .</span></b><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/2-MG-ayAzkQ/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/2-MG-ayAzkQ?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The nursing gel pads\nyou can buy that slip inside a maternity bra will help prevent chafing.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">After a run, or at\nnight when you're watching TV, be sure to ice the knee and joints. Pop an\nibuprofen if needed &nbsp;if the soreness&nbsp; prevents you from sleeping (not Tylenol /\nParacetmaol \u2013 which are EXTREMELY bad &nbsp;for your liver), but NEVER become too\ndependent on pain relievers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The changes happening\nin our body when we run frequently, or we start running more, include:---</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Improved cardiovascular\nfitness -- blood is pumped around body more effectively;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fat loss may occur as\nwe are using energy stored in fat for running energy;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Increased muscle\nbreakdown, wear and tear;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Increased muscle mass,\nif fuelling correctly;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dehydration and changes\nto electrolyte balance;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Improved mood due to\nincreased endorphins ('runner's high');<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Knee/joint pain from\nrepeated impact on hard surfaces ( barefoot runner are prone )<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During exercise, muscle\noxygen consumption increases up to 70 times above resting values. This enables\nmore oxygen, nutrients and hormones to be delivered to the muscles, and allows\nfor better removal of heat.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Aerobic (endurance)\ntraining also increases the muscles' ability to use oxygen to produce movement\nand improves their ability to store glycogen.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Preparing for\nmarathon--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maintain adequate\nhydration leading up to the event/exercise session;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Eat consistently during\nthe days leading up to the event and ensure sufficient calorie intake is\nmaintained;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Stick to clean and lean\nfoods avoiding excess salt, refined sugars and preservatives;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Focus your diet around\ncomplex carbohydrates (e.g. whole grain bread, rice, sweet potato etc.) to\nbuild up a glycogen supply to tap into during the event;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Avoid heavy fatty foods\nwhich may cause feelings of being weighed down<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Proteins are\nnitrogen-containing foods that contain different combinations of 20 amino\nacids. Nine of those amino acids are considered essential, meaning that our\nbodies cannot make them and we therefore need to consume them in foods on a\nregular basis.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Protein intake is critical for muscle repair and synthesis as\nwell as production of hormones, enzymes and hemoglobin, and contributes greatly\nto satiety (feeling of fullness) and immune function.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Inadequate total\nprotein intake &nbsp;by a marathon runner\nafter a grueling run could lead to muscle breakdown, poor recovery, increased\ninjury rate and compromised immune function.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">How much is too much?\nThe absorption rate of protein from the GI tract varies with type of protein\neaten but reaches a max of 10 grams per hour. Also, excessive protein intake\nthat exceeds the liver\u2019s ability to convert excess nitrogen to urea stresses\nthe body and can lead to increases in ammonia and insulin, as well as nausea,\ndiarrhea and calcium loss, and increases overall fluid needs.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Finally, when\nprotein intake exceeds need, it is likely that other nutritious foods\u2014and\ntherefore critical nutrients, vitamins and minerals\u2014are being \u201ccrowded out\u201d and\ndeficiencies may result.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Marathon runners &nbsp;are all too familiar with the message that\ncarbohydrates are the most important food to eat. Carbohydrates fuel muscles\nlike petrol your car. Muscle is comprised of many components: connective,\nnerves, blood capillaries, and muscle cells. All these have a common building\nblock: proteins.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are thousands of proteins in your body with many\ndifferent structures and functions. The building blocks for these proteins come\nfrom our diet.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During marathon running,\nproteins can be broken down to provide 3 to 5% of the total energy expenditure.\nWhen muscle glycogen becomes low, or if initial glycogen stores are low, energy\ncontribution from protein can be up to 10%.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One way to prevent the\nbreakdown of muscle protein for fuel is to provide adequate carbohydrate.&nbsp; &nbsp;Many\nendurance athletes think that eating a lot of carbohydrates is enough to\nprotect precious muscle protein.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Indeed, insulin, the hormone secreted in\nresponse to ingesting carbohydrates, helps protect muscle from protein\ndegradation. Still, insulin alone does not increase protein synthesis. Insulin\ncombined with amino acids is optimal for a positive protein balance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Adding protein to\nendurance sports carbohydrate beverages,&nbsp;\nwill impair gastric emptying and thus be ineffective in preventing\ndehydration when exercising in the heat.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">A runner who weighs 60\nkgs will burn 2,224 calories ( Kilo Calories ) during a marathon, a &nbsp;75 kg runner will burn 2,822 calories and a &nbsp;95 kg runner will burn 3,593 calories.</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again, one of the most\ncommon physiological changes during a marathon is glycogen depletion, where all\nthe \u201cquick\u201d energy from carbohydrates is recruited from either blood glucose or\nmuscular glycogen stores to sustain forward motion during the race.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;During\nprolonged strenuous exercise lasting longer than 90 minutes, glucose in the\nblood is the first to be depleted, which then signals the liver to begin\nconverting muscular glycogen into blood glucose.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once the liver has depleted\nthe muscular glycogen stores, the body begins to burn fat for fuel, which,\ncombined with dehydration, results in muscle cramping and the feeling of\n\u201chitting the wall\u201d late in the race.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hitting the infamous\nwall during a marathon can be a truly miserable experience. Hitting the wall or\n\u201cbonking\u201d is a well-known phenomena among ultra runners and occurs when the\nbody runs out of sugar to use for physiological processes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Super-humans \u2013 our\nso-called champions \u2013 are not just the result of hard training or genetics.\nThey are the result of smart training combined with excellent genetics.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During a marathon, core\nbody temperature can increase by almost 3\u00b0F/1\u00b0C due to dehydration and\nincreases in metabolic rate, which describes the energy expended during the\nrace.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For some people, fifteen times the amount of energy normally expended at\nrest will be consumed during a marathon. Since the burning of energy is an\nexothermic process (i.e. heat is produced), the body\u2019s basal temperature rises\nas a result.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">To efficiently cool the\nbody, warm blood is pumped through the body towards the skin, where heat is\nlost due to evaporation of sweat. The increase in heat production during a\nmarathon makes efficient cooling more difficult.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Additionally, dehydration\ndecreases blood volume which inhibits the body\u2019s natural cooling mechanism.\nAlthough normal body temperature is 98.6\u00b0 F/37\u00b0 C, marathon finishers often are\nreported to have core temperatures near 105\u00b0 F/41\u00b0 C. Temperatures in excess of\n107\u00b0 F/42\u00b0 C are fatal.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Running a marathon has been\nshown to produce mild damage to cardiac tissue, as evidenced by elevated levels\nof troponin, creatine kinase and creatine kinase myglobin in the blood stream.\nThe elevation of these proteins, which are direct results of cardiac tissue\ndeath, can last for up to a month post-race..</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Muscles that are fatigued lose their strength,\nand thus their ability to protect joints. For example, take that favourite\ninjury, the shin splints.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">While you are running, you rely on one particular\nmuscle to take proportionately more strain. It is a strip of sinew that runs\ndown the shin to the inside edge of the foot and pulls the foot inward and\nupward.</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">During running, this muscle works at least twice as hard as other local\nmuscles, and is therefore most likely to fatigue first. As it gets tired, the\nrisk of shin splints and stress fractures is likely to rise, as does the risk\nof knee injuries</span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">.</span></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">During the first hour of exercise, most of your\nenergy comes from glycogen stored in your muscles.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">After about an hour, the muscles begin to\ndraw their fuel from the blood sugar, which is in turn supplied by glycogen\nstored in your liver, as well as from their own stores.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Your liver glycogen levels are also\nfinite.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">So when your liver glycogen is\ndepleted, your blood sugar level falls and you are unable to carry on\nexercising.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">This low blood sugar (called\n\u201chypoglycaemia\u201d) induces a feeling of tiredness and light-headedness, and your\nlegs begin to feel very heavy.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 115%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">.</span>.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/q6cp4M5Pw8M/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/q6cp4M5Pw8M?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">An alternative to using\nsports drinks to maintain your blood sugar levels is to use gels.&nbsp; These are sachets sold in specialist running\nand fitness shops, which contain a sugary syrup designed to be taken during\nlong runs and races.&nbsp; Each sachet\ncontains around 20g of carbohydrate, so you can usefully take 2-3 each hour.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The main advantage of\ngel sachets is that they are easy to carry in a pocket, or tucked into your\nwaistband.&nbsp; This means that you can take\nthem on training runs as well as during a race, so that you can train using the\nsame energy source as that which you will be using on race day itself.&nbsp; (By contrast, you can\u2019t easily do this with a\nsports drink, since you would have to carry a lot of sports drink on your\ntraining runs.)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The gel sachets should\nbe washed down with water (otherwise they are too concentrated and sickly), so\nmost runners take them as they approach a water aid station.&nbsp; To get the right concentration, you need to\nwash down a full sachet with about 250ml of water (more than a full paper\ncup).&nbsp; If this is too much water to drink\nin one go while you are running, then take less than a full sachet at each\nwater station.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For those running a\nmarathon, learning the difference between aerobic running and anaerobic running\nis even more critical. The faster you run the more energy you use. During the\nmarathon, you need to conserve as much fuel as possible, so if you run faster\nthan your aerobic threshold (the point at which you go from running 100%\naerobically to producing lactic acid) you will burn through your fuel stores\nfaster and more than likely hit the wall before you finish.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-zOaEVfWvnr0/V-L0BHmQIVI/AAAAAAABMAg/3b0nuDlnl-w1uMVuBoTLwuqokldvs2DTQCLcB/s1600/andaptations.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"360\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-zOaEVfWvnr0/V-L0BHmQIVI/AAAAAAABMAg/3b0nuDlnl-w1uMVuBoTLwuqokldvs2DTQCLcB/s640/andaptations.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/XkADvTlI6Sc/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/XkADvTlI6Sc?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bleeding women rarely\nwin marathons. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The menstrual cycle is\ncomprised of two phases.&nbsp; During the\nFollicular Phase (Days 1-14), estrogen levels are low, except for a spike near\nDay 14.&nbsp; Ovulation begins on Day 15.&nbsp; The Luteal Phase (Days 16-28) is marked by\nrelatively high but stable estrogen levels.&nbsp;\nAlso, progesterone levels peak, inducing a much-higher-than-normal\nbreathing rate during exercise.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many women have cycles\nthat are either longer or shorter than the textbook 28 days.&nbsp; In these cases, it is the length of the\nfollicular (pre-ovulatory) phase that varies; the luteal (post-ovulatory) cycle\nis usually of stable duration.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Not only does estrogen\nlevel affect your cycle, it also impacts&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">what type of fuel is\navailable for working muscles and consequently&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">what type of workout\nyou will find easier to complete</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Low estrogen levels are\nconducive to breaking down glycogen for quick energy.&nbsp; High estrogen levels favour fat burning and\nlower lactic acid levels.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many women\nfind that during Days 4-13 (corresponding with low estrogen levels) high\nintensity runs are easier to complete, with lower heart rates and breathing\nrates (less perceived exertion).&nbsp; These\nconditions are ideal for hard running and racing.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In contrast, many women\nfind that hard running during Days 14 \u2013 28 is very difficult, as the\nutilization of fat for fuel is better suited for lower intensity workouts.&nbsp; Consequently, your long runs at an easier\npace are sustainable.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Luteal Phase occurs for\n14 days in all women. As the ovulation occurs on the 14th day, there is an\nincrease in the progesterone level which causes a rise in the body temperature\nto prepare the right environment for the fertilisation of the released egg. As\nsoon as ovulation occurs, estrogen levels begin to decrease.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When there is no\nfertilisation, there is a sudden decrease in the levels of both estrogen and\nprogesterone. Luteal phase ends, menses or periods start, marking the beginning\nof another menstrual cycle.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Estrogen enhances fat\nuse, which spares glycogen.&nbsp; So technically\nyour ability to run for long periods is influenced by the amount of glycogen in\nyour muscles, by sparing the amount used and relying more on fat for energy,\nfatigue is delayed and your endurance is improved. &nbsp;&nbsp;Technically Bill Clinton did NOT have sex\nwith Monica Lewisnsky. TEE HEEEE !<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Within the U.S. team\nalone, 292 of the 555 athletes in Rio are female \u2014 the most women who have\ncompeted for any country in the games' history, according to the U.S. Olympic\nCommittee.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">So some women were\ncertainly menstruating. And as any woman knows, a monthly cycle can bring on\ncramps and fatigue, making even a regular workday harder.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Add that to the stress\nof competing under a global spotlight. It's one less stressor male athletes\nhave to worry about.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Afflicted by cramps,\nChinese swimmer Fu Yuanhui addressed her period during an interview in Rio.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the interviewer\nasked if she was experiencing stomach pain, she said, \"My period started\nlast night. So I'm feeling pretty weak, and really tired.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yuanhui added that it\nwasn't an excuse for just missing a medal in the race.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Her mention of period\ncramps was a rare display of openness about menstruation in athletics, and it\ncreated a buzz of support within China's social media.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot;
