text-align: left;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-jHF_QwcUUM0/V935QT_eG9I/AAAAAAABL9U/IrlGiXXGeXwi2-8g_RUAjdkMM5fyoO0QwCLcB/s1600/coward-qFFuotes-3.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"300\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-jHF_QwcUUM0/V935QT_eG9I/AAAAAAABL9U/IrlGiXXGeXwi2-8g_RUAjdkMM5fyoO0QwCLcB/s640/coward-qFFuotes-3.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>SO SO SO--</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>MR MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>COWARDICE IS COURAGE?</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>SUNRISE IS SUNSET ?</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>BLACK IS WHITE ?</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>OH FUCKIN' YEAH ?</b></span><br />\n<br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When you work out, you\nstress the fibers in your muscles, causing them to break down. As these muscle\nfibers break down, your body responds by processing the by-products of intense\nmuscular exertion (a complex chemical and mitochondrial process), which is also\nreferred to as muscular acidosis, or lactic acid build up in the muscle tissue.\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This process is\naccompanied by an aching soreness, varying from mild discomfort to serious\npain. You will most likely feel the most soreness (related to your body\nprocessing the lactic acid buildup in your recovering muscle fibers) the second\nand third day after an intense workout.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vitamin C and\npotassium&nbsp; speed the recovery and repair\nthe stressed muscle fibers. Vitamin C can be found in citrus juice and supplements.\nPotassium is found in bananas and coconut water . <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fresh coconut water\nwould be an excellent marathon drink\u2014&nbsp;&nbsp;\nif you consume some salt extra (sodium and chloride ) SEPARATE <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2011/02/quantum-drink-coconut-water-capt-ajit.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2011/02/quantum-drink-coconut-water-capt-ajit.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By drinking plenty of\nwater, you can flush your body of excess lactic acid.&nbsp;&nbsp; When you take the time to stretch after\nexercising, you allow the muscles to release some of the lactic acid building\nup in the muscles. After several workouts, you\u2019ll find your muscles suffer less\nand less from pain related to lactic acid build up. This is because the muscles\nadapt to the strain placed upon them.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pain is a warning\nmechanism the threat of injury, to bodily tissues.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">So that we don\u2019t need\nto keep eating carbohydrates every hour of the day to meet demand, the body\nstores carbohydrate away in our muscles and liver in the form of a substance\nknown as glycogen. As a runner, you rely on this stored carbohydrate to help you\nkeep going.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During your training or\nracing, without a sufficient amount of glycogen, you will slowly grind to a\nhalt. Although protein and fat stores can used to fuel movement, they are much\nmore difficult to breakdown and utilise as a fast source of energy. Fat can be\nused and indeed is used to help fuel movement, but it is your carbohydrate\nnutrition needs to be spot on if you want to perform.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The human body can\nstore somewhere in the region of 500g (1.1lb) of carbohydrate in the form of\nglycogen. 100g of which is stored in the liver and 400g is stored in the\nmuscles. These stores are enough to take you to about thirty kilometres of the\nmarathon.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is the point where\npeople say they hit the dreaded wall because without sufficient glycogen, a\nquick energy source is unavailable, causing the body to turn to alternative\nstores of energy such as fat and protein to keep movement sustained.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nprocess of converting fat and protein into quick energy is complex and the body\nis unable to do it quickly enough to meet energy demands, ultimately leading to\ndeterioration in performance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If carbohydrate stores\nremain low, an insufficient supply of sugar is available to keep the brain\nworking properly, giving rise to symptoms of dizziness and confusion. If\nexercise is continued with these symptoms, a runner\u2019s health can very quickly\ndeteriorate causing the athlete to collapse and fall very ill.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Marathon runners &nbsp;need considerable amounts of protein, far\nabove the normal adult RDA, because maintenance, repair, and growth of lean\nmuscle mass all depend on it, as well as optimum immune system function. Low\ndietary protein lengthens recovery time, causes muscle weakness, and suppresses\nthe immune system.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chronic protein deficiency will cancel the beneficial\neffects of your workouts; instead, you will become susceptible to fatigue,\nlethargy, anemia, and possibly even more severe disorders. Athletes with over\ntraining syndrome usually have protein deficiency. Protein requirement of\nathletes is higher than those of sedentary people.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It takes care of muscle trauma that results\nfrom frequent muscle contraction and for healing of injuries to muscle fibres.\nHigh intensity, continued exercises for a long duration increases oxidation of\namino acids for fuelling our body and protein is used as an energy. This makes\na greater influence to total energy production during endurance exercise when\nmuscle glycogen levels are low.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Intensive marathon\nexercise can lead to muscle tissue loss. Eating sufficient calories,\ncarbohydrates and protein will help keep away this wasting. Endurance training\npushes protein needs to 25% to 50% more than of DV (daily value). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">No matter what time you\nrun but what you eat post your run may determine the quality of your next\nworkout and a combination of carbohydrate and protein, 30 minutes after hard\nrunning can rebuild glycogen stores better than carbohydrates alone. This combo\nalso speed muscle recovery.&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">DO NOT GO FOR BODY\nBUILDING SUPPLEMENTS<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/08/body-building-supplements-and-their.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/08/body-building-supplements-and-their.html</a><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When you run, you sweat. The more you sweat\nthe more your blood volume decreases. The more your blood volume decreases, the\nharder your heart has to work to deliver oxygen to your muscle.&nbsp;&nbsp; Normal level of dehydration will make you\nfeel uncomfortable and cause you to slow down.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: #f1c232;\">Drinking water loaded with right amount of electrolyte (\nPERSONALISED&nbsp; DRINK ) while you run will\nlimit these negative effect of dehydration. OP Jaisha was denied of this drink. &nbsp;This personalised drink is different at every 10 kms of the race .</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The signs of moderate\ndehydration include:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Thirst<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Very dry mouth<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Sunken eyes<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Sunken fontanelles\n(the soft spots on an infant\u2019s head)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Tenting (pinch and\nlift skin lightly\u2014if it doesn\u2019t bounce back readily)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Low or no urine\noutput<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Not producing tears<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Signs of severe\ndehydration include:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 All signs of moderate\ndehydration<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Rapid and weak pulse<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Cold hands and feet<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Rapid breathing<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Blue lips<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Lethargic, comatose,\nseizures<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Severe dehydration\nrequires immediate hospitalization.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For every one percent\nof body weight lost, blood volume decreases by 2.5 percent, muscle water\ndecreases by one percent, and the body\u2019s core temperature can increase 0.4 to\n0.5\u00b0 C.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">OP Jaisha while in a semi-coma\nwas placed on a block of ice to reduce her body core temperature--she would have died .</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Changes in blood volume during prolonged\nexercise impair the body\u2019s ability to deliver oxygen and key nutrients to\nactive muscles, organs, and glands and negatively affect thermoregulation (the\nbody\u2019s ability to regulate core body temperature) by diminishing the body\u2019s\nability to expel heat.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Losses of three percent are associated with\nphysiological changes, such as decreased blood volume, decreased urine output,\ndiminished performance, and decreased endurance, while losses of nine to twelve\npercent are fatal.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As an essential\nmineral, an electrolyte cannot be substituted by any other nutrient in the\ndiet. That means that your body will only accept that particular mineral or\nelectrolyte.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Without electrolytes,\nyou could not move, think, or live. Within the body, electrolytes are dissolved\nin body fluids. In terms of hydration, electrolytes are responsible for\ndirecting water (and nutrients) to the areas of the body where its needed most\nand maintaining optimal fluid balance inside the cells.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Besides maintaining\nfluid balance, electrolytes help your muscles to contract and relax and assist\nin the transmission of nerve impulses&nbsp;\nfrom your nervous system to different body parts.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/DZDqIoKzvEg/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/DZDqIoKzvEg?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thermoregulation is the\nprocess that allows the human body to maintain its core internal temperature.\nThe state of having an even internal temperature is called homeostasis. All\nthermoregulation mechanisms are designed to return the body to homeostasis.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In thermoregulation, body\nheat is generated mostly in the deep organs, especially the liver, brain, and\nheart, and in contraction of skeletal muscles. Humans have been able to\nadapt to a great diversity of climates, including hot humid and hot arid. High\ntemperatures pose serious stresses for the human body, placing it in great\ndanger of injury or even death.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are four avenues\nof heat loss: convection, conduction, radiation, and evaporation. If skin\ntemperature is greater than that of the surroundings, the body can lose heat by\nradiation and conduction. But, if the temperature of the surroundings is\ngreater than that of the skin, the body actually gains heat by radiation and\nconduction.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In such conditions, the only means by which the body can rid itself\nof heat is by evaporation. So, when the surrounding temperature is higher than\nthe skin temperature, anything that prevents adequate evaporation will cause\nthe internal body temperature to rise. During sports activities, evaporation\nbecomes the main avenue of heat loss.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Humidity affects thermoregulation by\nlimiting sweat evaporation and thus heat loss<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The core temperature of\na human is regulated and stabilized primarily by the hypothalamus, a region of\nthe brain linking the endocrine system to the nervous system<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maintaining a stable\ninternal environment in a person means having to carefully regulate countless\nparameters which include:--</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">body temperature<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">internal pH<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">internal concentrations\nof various ions<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">hydration<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">blood pressure<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">glucose levels in the\nblood.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">So, how do our bodies\ndo all of this and keep track of everything at the same time? Well, for the\nmost part, our bodies keep track of all of these different conditions\nseparately, and then make adjustments one or two parameters at a time before\nsomething gets too far out of the normal range and starts affecting an\nimportant function.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Humans, along with all\nother birds and mammals are endotherms which means that they are animals that\nactively maintain a stable body temperature by generating heat. People sometimes\ncall endotherms warm-blooded animals. In contrast, most other animals like\nreptiles, fish, and insects are ectotherms which are animals whose body\ntemperature changes with their environment. People usually call ectotherms\ncold-blooded animals.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A stable body\ntemperature of 98.7 degrees Fahrenheit, is one aspect of homeostasis in humans.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The main advantage of\nhaving a stable body temperature is that it allows optimization of normal body\nfunctions, metabolism and enzymes to a specific set temperature. This ensures\nthat no matter what the environmental conditions, as long as the animal\nmaintains temperature homeostasis, it will still be able to perform all normal\nbody functions at or near optimal levels<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If your body needs to\ncool down, these include:--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sweating: Sweating is\none of the first methods your body will use to control your temperature. Sweat\ncools your skin as it evaporates. This helps lower your internal temperature.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vasodilatation: Your\nCNS may instruct the capillaries under the surface of your skin to dilate, or\nopen. Vasodilatation, or enlarged capillaries, increases blood flow at the skin\nsurface. This lets your body release heat through radiation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All known higher\nlifeforms require a subtle and complex electrolyte balance between the\nintracellular and extracellular fluids. The maintenance of precise osmotic\ngradients of electrolytes is important. Such gradients affect and regulate the\nhydration of the body as well as blood pH, and are critical for nerve and\nmuscle function.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Endurance performance\nis compromised more by warmer temperatures than by cooler temperatures. Here\u2019s\nwhy: to control an excessive rise in body temperature, the blood flow to the\nskin increases in order to dissipate heat to the environment. This shift of\nblood to the skin will result in a lesser proportion of blood and, hence,\noxygen being delivered to the working muscle. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In some individuals the\ncirculatory adjustments may not be adequate, and the body temperature will rise\nrapidly, leading to hyperthermia (excessive body heat). Individual sweat rates\nvary, but those that sweat early, heavily, and cake with salt tend to be more\nprone to muscle cramps.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again, hydrating with\nwater alone can lead to water intoxication and an electrolyte imbalance.&nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Muscles are much more\nlikely to cramp when fatigued.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The fitter and better\ntrained you are for your event, the lower the risk of muscle cramps.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because all electrical\nsignalling activity in the muscles takes place in an aqueous (water)\nenvironment and even small shortfalls in hydration levels could lead to\nimpaired electrical signalling and an increased risk of cramping.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even small drops in the\nlevel of stored muscle carbohydrate (glycogen \u2013 your body\u2019s premium fuel for\nexercise) can lead to increased fatigue, which may in turn increases the risk\nof muscle cramps.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Oral Rehydration Salts\n(ORS) are a \"must have\" for marathoners, ultra runners, and all\nendurance athletes. ORS contain important electrolytes, in a base of dextrose,\nto enhance the body's ability to quickly absorb fluids during exercise.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As a general rule, in\nthe 2 hours leading up to a endurance sports event, you should drink around\n500ml of an O.R.S Hydration drink, to ensure your body is optimally hydrated.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Glycogen stores glucose\nin the body and you need glucose for energy. When you lose glycogen, you reach\na point of \u201chitting the wall\u201d when you feel sapped of energy and unable to\ncontinue.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The phrase \u201chitting the\nwall\u201d during a race refers to the point in which you\u2019ve used up all your\nglycogen stores and have started to burn fat. At this time, fatigue sets in,\nand the end of your competition is in sight whether or not you want it to be.\nModifications in your diet to consume more carbohydrates can increase your\nglycogen stores, enabling you to exercise longer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During aerobic\nexercise, you need oxygen to get energy from stored carbohydrates. Once your\ncarbohydrates, or glycogen stores, are gone, your body relies on fat. Fat\nmetabolism is a less efficient process, so your performance declines and\nfatigue takes over.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During an aerobic\nworkout, you depend on liver glycogen to keep your blood sugar levels steady.\nAt a moderately steady pace of exercise, you metabolize blood glucose at 1 gram\nper minute or 60 grams per hour .&nbsp; Once\nliver glycogen is gone, your blood sugar levels drop and your workout or event\nis negatively affected.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The better conditioned\nyou are and the more carbohydrates you eat, the more efficient your muscles are\nat storing glycogen. With more glycogen stores, you can exercise longer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One thing you shouldn\u2019t\ndo is fill your belly with water just before you go running.&nbsp; Doing this will affect your performance and\nyou\u2019ll be conscious of the water moving around inside you.&nbsp; GLUG GLUG GLUG&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_35M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/09/marathon-running-secrets-of_17.html?showComment=1474201464378#c6532704638009154560\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">September 18, 2016 at 5:54 PM</a></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_35MC\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nUS GYMNAST SIMON BILES IS A STATE SPONSORED DRUG CHEAT<br />\n<br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\">EVERYBODY KNOWS THE US BASEBALL LEAGUE IS FULL OF ADDERALL CHEATS</span></b><br />\n<br />\nUS NATIONAL NEWSPAPER HAD DONE HEADLINES ABOUT THE EPIDEMIC OF ADHD BASEBALL PLAYERS -- ONLY BECAUSE THEY WANT AN EDGE WITH ADDERALL<br />\n<br />\nAdderall is comprised of mixed amphetamine salts, namely 75% dextroamphetamine and 25% levoamphetamine. It functions by increasing levels and inhibiting reuptake of stimulatory neurotransmitters such as dopamine and norepinephrine. Adderall remains a popular drug among college students for studying and passing tests. In US sex orgy parties in dorms they do NOT snort cocaine any more. They snort Adderall for that rapidly-induced euphoria.<br />\n<br />\nSimon Biles also used Focalin as a prescription drug to cheat.<br />\nBoth Focalin and Adderall inhibit the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine, thus increasing their extracellular levels.<br />\n<br />\nFocalin\u2019s strength is TRIPLE that of banned \u201cdexmethylphenidate\u201d (d-threo-methylphenidate) or D-TMP. It contains solely the dextrorotatory (right-handed) stereoisomer of methylphenidate<br />\n<br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\">SIMONE BILES THE US STATE SPONSORED CHEAT DEPRIVED DIPA KARMAKAR OF A BRONZE MEDAL AT RIO OLYMPICS . .</span></b><br />\n<br />\nCHEATING IS A CHOICE --NEVER AN INADVERTENT MISTAKE. .<br />\n<br />\nDAMN SIMONE BILES !<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/GW7-PeFaUjc/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/GW7-PeFaUjc?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dextrose anhydrous is\nthe purest form of dextrose, commonly called glucose. It is manufactured by\nrefining dextrose monohydrate, itself a pure form of dextrose. Dextrose\nanhydrous provides instant energy. It is the primary ingredient in oral\nrehydration salts (ORS).</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/tGmaA6koDk4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/tGmaA6koDk4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dextrose anhydrous is used in intravenous (IV) fluids\nto provide nutrients to patients under intensive care ( fainted athelete like\nOP Jaisha&nbsp; )&nbsp; who are unable to receive them by the oral\nroute. Dextrose anhydrous complements the function of saline solution for a\ntotal electrolyte-energy balance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">What happens during\nsweating? Initially, water moves from tissue to blood as sweat is lost, to keep\nelectrolytes within normal physiological levels. Finally a breaking point is\nreached when the body can no longer compensate by removing water from tissue,\nand then plasma volume begins to decrease.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nowadays marathon\nrunners wear&nbsp; cool vests as means to keep\ntheir core body temperature down prior to starting their race.&nbsp; A cool vest can be mimicked by placing ice\npacks around your core as you stretch prior to a race.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-uqi4YMY8mVs/V97vUAXXntI/AAAAAAABL-U/sJbY0rtwo6U-rTMq88JemRfyQ0BqVJHAwCLcB/s1600/nike-precssool-vest.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"424\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-uqi4YMY8mVs/V97vUAXXntI/AAAAAAABL-U/sJbY0rtwo6U-rTMq88JemRfyQ0BqVJHAwCLcB/s640/nike-precssool-vest.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ions that are\nformed when electrolytes are dissolved in body fluids are either positively or\nnegatively charged. Positively charged ions are called cations, and are formed\nwhen an atom or atom group loses electrons.&nbsp;\nAnion is an ion carrying a negative charge owing to a surplus of\nelectrons. Anions in the body include bicarbonate, chloride, phosphate,\nsulfate, certain organic acids, and certain protein compounds. Ion is an atom\nthat acquires an electrical charge by the gain or loss of electrons.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbohydrate is stored\nas glucose in the liver and muscles and is the most efficient source of energy\nas it requires less oxygen to be burnt than either Protein or fat. The normal\nbody stores of carbohydrate in a typical athlete are:--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">70kg male athlete -\nLiver glycogen 90g and muscle glycogen 400g<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">60kg female athlete -\nLiver glycogen 70g and muscle glycogen 300g.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During hard exercise,\ncarbohydrate can be depleted at a rate of 3-4 grams per minute. If this is\nsustained for 2 hours or more, a very large fraction of the total body\ncarbohydrate stores will be exhausted and if not checked will result in reduced\nperformance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During exercise, there\nis in an increased uptake of blood glucose by the muscles and to prevent blood\nglucose levels falling the liver produces glucose from the liver stores and\nlactate.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Consuming carbohydrate\nbefore, during and after exercise will help prevent blood glucose levels\nfalling too low and help maintain the body's glycogen stores. Pure water\ncontains no carbohydrate or electrolytes<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are three types\nof sports drink all of which contain various levels of fluid, electrolytes and\ncarbohydrate.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Type&nbsp; &nbsp;/&nbsp;Content<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Isotonic&nbsp; / &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Fluid, &nbsp;electrolytes and 6 to 8%\ncarbohydrate<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hypotonic/&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Fluids, electrolytes and a low level of\ncarbohydrate<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hypertonic/&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; High level of carbohydrate<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The osmolality of a\nfluid is a measure of the number of particles in a solution. In a drink, these\nparticles will comprise of carbohydrate, electrolytes, sweeteners and\npreservatives.. Blood has an osmolality of 280 to 330mOsm/kg. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Drinks with an\nosmolality of 270 to 330mOsm/kg are said to be in balance with the body's fluid\nand are called Isotonic. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\">Isotonic fluids </span></b><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\">quickly\nreplaces fluids lost by sweating and supplies a boost of carbohydrate. This\ndrink is the choice for most athletes - middle and long distance running or\nteam sports. Glucose is the body's preferred source of energy therefore it may\nbe appropriate to consume Isotonic drinks where the carbohydrate source is\nglucose in a concentration of 6% to 8%.&nbsp;\nIsotonic fluids have the same concentration as normal bodily fluids and\nso easily absorbed;&nbsp; commercial isotonic\ndrinks typically contain 4g \u2013 8g of carbohydrate per 100ml.&nbsp; Isotonic drinks balance the need for\nrehydration and refueling.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\">Hypotonic fluids </span></b><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\">have\nfewer particles than blood and Hypertonic have more particles than blood. Hypotonic&nbsp; fluids quickly replaces fluids lost by\nsweating.&nbsp; They are suitable for athletes\nwho need fluid without the boost of carbohydrate e.g. jockeys and\ngymnasts.&nbsp;&nbsp; Hypotonic fluids are&nbsp; less concentrated than normal bodily fluids;\ntypically less than 4g of carbohydrate per 100ml.&nbsp; They are absorbed faster than plain water,\nbut containing less carbohydrate than isotonic drinks. Hypotonic drinks have a\nlower concentration of solutes / salt than the normal concentration that exists\nin our cells in our bodies, which means we absorb hypotonic drinks quickly.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><span style=\"color: red;\">Hypertonic&nbsp; fluids</span> </span></b><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\">are used to supplement daily\ncarbohydrate intake normally after exercise to top up muscle glycogen\nstores.&nbsp;&nbsp; In marathon&nbsp; events, high levels of energy are required\nand hypertonic drinks can be taken during exercise to meet the energy demands.\nIf used during exercise hypertonic drinks need to be used in conjunction with\nIsotonic drinks to replace fluids. Hypertonic&nbsp;\nfluids are&nbsp; more concentrated than\nnormal bodily fluids; usually containing more than 8g of carbohydrate per\n100ml; because of their concentration they are absorbed more slowly than\nisotonic drinks.&nbsp; These are better saved\nas post-run drinks, if you are wanting some extra carbohydrate.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If the weather is hot,\nyou should give more priority to fluid replacement, and choose a hypotonic or\nisotonic drink<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The absorption of\nfluids into the body is largely dependent upon two factors: (1) the rate at\nwhich it is absorbed through the walls of the small intestine; and (2) the\nspeed at which it is emptied from the stomach. Both of these factors are\ncontrolled by the composition of a liquid in terms of its carbohydrate (sugar),\nand electrolyte concentrations.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As a general rule, the\nhigher the carbohydrate content of your beverage, the slower the absorption\nrate will be. Consequently, trying to maintain proper hydration and balanced\nelectrolyte levels during a run with sugary sports drinks is difficult.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most sports drinks on\nthe market are what sports scientists call isotonic, which means they contain a\ncarbohydrate solution that is at 6-8% concentration. These drinks are in the\nmiddle of the spectrum in terms of absorption rate, with water being the most\nreadily absorbed (hypotonic) and something like fruit juice, being greater than\n8% sugar concentration (hypertonic) being the least absorbable.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because the sugar\nconcentration of most sports drinks is higher than that of most body fluid they\nare not readily absorbed into the blood stream and are thus not optimal for\nhydration.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When a runner consumes\nhigh-glycemic (Gl) foods, like high-sugar sports drinks or energy bars, an hour\nbefore a run, he or she may become fatigued more quickly.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The most efficient way to rehydrate properly\nis to put back exactly how much fluid you\u2019ve lost while running. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The rate of passage of\nwater from your stomach into your small intestine depends on how much fluid is\nactually in your stomach. If there is lots of water there, fluid flow from\nstomach to intestine is like a springtime flood; if there is little water, the\nmovement resembles a lightly dripping tap. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Intracellular fluid and\ninterstitial fluid have the same osmotic pressures under normal circumstances<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The first result, an\nincrease in intracellular water concentration, called over hydration which\ndisrupts nerve cell function.&nbsp; In severe\nover hydration we may see disoriented behaviour, convulsions, coma, and even death<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The second result is a\nloss of interstitial fluid volume that leads to a decrease in the interstitial\nfluid pressure. As the pressure drops, water moves out of the plasma, resulting\nin a loss of blood volume that may lead to circulatory shock.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbohydrates or\n\u201ccarbs\u201d (found in pasta, bread,&nbsp; rice,\ngrains, potatoes, etc.) are especially important for athletes because they\nsupply the body with glucose for energy. Extra glucose is stored in the muscles\nand liver as glycogen, your energy reserve.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During short bursts of exercise\nsuch as sprinting, basketball, gymnastics, or soccer, your body relies on\nglycogen to keep your blood sugar levels stable and thus maintain your energy.\nIf you don\u2019t have enough glycogen, you may feel very tired or have difficulty\nsustaining the activity \u2013 effects that will, undoubtedly, impact your\nperformance!&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During longer exercise, your body uses your glycogen stores first,\nnext turning to fats stored in your body to fuel performance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fat is an important\nsource of energy used to fuel longer exercise and endurance activities, such as\nmarathon running.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Eating a diet that is too low in dietary fat may decrease\nathletic performance and cause other health problems, such as deficiencies of\ncertain vitamins, which require fat to be absorbed. Good sources of fat include\nDESI ghee,&nbsp; virgin coconut oil, salmon,\nnuts <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Protein is needed for\nyour body to build and repair muscles. Small amounts of protein may also be\nused for energy. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Eat enough calories.\nCalories fuel your body for exercise and replace energy that is used up during\nsports performance. Cutting calories keeps you from performing your best. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Do not wait until you\nare thirsty to start drinking water, because thirst means that you are starting\nto dehydrate. Remember to drink even more in hot and humid weather.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">You can figure out if\nyou\u2019re well hydrated by looking at the color of your urine. A clear color is a\nsign of good hydration. However, if you see a darker yellow color, this means\nthat you need to drink more fluids. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sugars and sweets\n(especially soda and candy) don\u2019t provide lasting energy, and therefore aren\u2019t\nrecommended to fuel your exercise.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Don\u2019t try new foods\nbefore a competition. You may have trouble digesting a food you have never\neaten before. Choose foods that are familiar to you.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again, Carbohydrate\nloading is a technique used to increase the amount of glycogen in muscles. It\ninvolves eating extra carbohydrates during the week before a competition, while\nat the same time cutting back on your training. Carbohydrate loading is\nintended for marathon runners .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Getting extra protein\nfrom supplements won\u2019t have any added benefit. Eating enough calories is\nactually more important for building muscle. Without enough calories, your body\ncan\u2019t build new muscle.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Your body has an incredibly complex system of\nsensors and feedback mechanisms to ensure smooth and appropriate muscle\nmovement at all times. Included in this system is a sensory receptor within\nyour tendons called the golgi tendon organ. When stretched, this receptor sends\ninhibitory signals to your spine preventing what are known as \u201calpha\u201d motor\nneurons from stimulating the muscle to contract.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As your muscles\nfatigue, though, this normal inhibitory mechanism somehow becomes weakened. The\nalpha motor neurons then receive less inhibition, and/or more stimulation, and\nthis ultimately leads to muscle cramping.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Your muscles contract\nwhen a signal from the motor cortex in the brain travels down your spinal cord\nthen out to the muscle fibres along the alpha motor nerve. Once there it\nstimulates the muscle to contract\u2026<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cSpindles\u201d (which are\ntiny structures in the muscle fibres) fire up and contract the muscle; this is\nto protect the muscle from overloading or over-stretching.&nbsp; the brains reaction to a muscle contraction\nis to activate the Golgi tendon organ reflex \u2013 the Golgi tendon organ sends a\nsignal to the spinal cord which inhibits the alpha motor neuron activity\n(contraction) and so the muscle relaxes..</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When muscle becomes\nfatigued the spindle activity increases and the Golgi tendon organ activity\ndecreases which, for you and me, means that the muscle keeps contracting and\nthen doesn\u2019t relax \u2013 or, simply put \u2013 \u2018cramp\u2019.. pace yourself to run more\nslowly, thus putting less strain on your muscles \u2013 in other words avoid pushing\nto your limits on long runs until you are accustomed to the distance,\nespecially marathons <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Runs lasting longer\nthan an hour take energy gels or sports drinks with you .&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Warm up your muscles\nbefore a run and warm down after \u2013 a 5 minute walk does the trick</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The excitatory stimulus\noverwhelms the inhibition from the Golgi tendon and alters the neuromuscular\ncontrol at the spinal level, which results in cramps. Stretching the muscle\ngroup restores muscle inhibition and relieves the cramp. Injury to a muscle\nand/or connective tissue leads to scar tissue and reduced flexibility <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The best time to\nstretch muscles is when they are warm, following exercise, Muscle's flexibility\nand range of motion is regulated by two sensory organs: muscle spindles and <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Golgi\ntendon</span> organs. These receptors work synergistically to communicate information\nregarding a muscle's length and actions to our central nervous system.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/t6DhSK_1fio/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/t6DhSK_1fio?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Muscle spindles consist\nof muscle fibres within the belly of a muscle. Within muscle spindles are nerve\nfibres with synapses at both ends that send nerve signals from one cell to the\nnext. Connective tissues surround muscle spindles, running parallel to muscle\nfibre alignment.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Muscle spindles send\nmessages to our central nervous system about the length and tension of a\nmuscle/s and the speed of contraction. When a muscle is stretched for a\nsustained length of time, muscle spindles become desensitised, decreasing the\nnumber of nerve signals sent to the central nervous system, allowing the muscle\nto lengthen further.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If we stretch a muscle\ntoo quickly or too far, it reacts the same way as a seat belt; the sudden\njarring jams the belt from being pulled further. We must release it before\npulling slowly again. Tugging at a seat belt repeatedly only shortens it. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Our muscles have a\nstretch reflex response that activates the same way to protect a muscle being\noverstretched or torn. This protective mechanism causes a muscle to become\nshortened and painful. Be patient when stretching (no bouncing or jerking) and\nfor safety stretch when muscles are warm<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fat exists in your body\nfor a reason. It is an excellent storage form for energy. For a given amount of\nmass, fat contains more than twice the amount of stored energy than\ncarbohydrates (9.3 kcal/gram versus 4.1 kcal/gram) <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">However, fat is NOT the\nmost efficient fuel for energy USAGE . Fat requires more than twice the amount\nof oxygen than carbohydrates to metabolize the same amount of mass (1.96 liters\nO2 per gram fat compared to 0.81 liters O2 per gram of carbohydrate). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For every liter of\noxygen you take in, you burn 0.51 grams of fat producing 4.74 kcal energy.
