, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/01/yoga-only-complete-exercise-part-2-capt.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/01/yoga-only-complete-exercise-part-2-capt.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Total body water can be\ndivided into two compartments \u2013 the intracellular space, which includes water\ninside muscle and brain cells, and the extracellular space, which includes\nfluid in the space between cells and the plasma.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In a 70 kg person the amount\nof water inside the cells is about 28 L and the amount of water outside the\ncells is about 14 L. The balance of water inside and outside the cells is\ndetermined in part by sodium intake as well as other electrolytes such as\npotassium and chloride.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sodium is the primary\nextracellular electrolyte. When sodium is consumed, it is distributed to the\nfluid outside of the cells, so sodium intake during exercise helps maintain blood\nsodium concentration.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sodium ingestion also helps retain fluid in the blood,\nwhich is important for maintaining or expanding plasma volume for rehydration\nand cardiovascular function.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The presence of sodium\nin a fluid replacement beverage is also important for whole-body fluid\nretention. For rehydration after exercise, the fluid consumed needs to stay in\nthe body as opposed to loss through urination.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When plain water is consumed,\nblood sodium concentration is diluted, turning off the signal to the kidney to\nreabsorb water and resulting in increased urine volume.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By contrast, when a sodium-containing\nbeverage is consumed, blood sodium concentration is increased, which in turn\nstimulates the reabsorption of water in the kidneys so that less urine is formed.\nIn fact, fluid retention increases in direct proportion to beverage sodium\nconcentration.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">To achieve rapid and\ncomplete rehydration after exercise, athletes should consume a moderate to\nhigh-sodium beverage in a volume equivalent to 150% of fluid loss. &nbsp;This extra fluid volume helps compensate for\nurine excreted during the rehydration process.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Overall it is important\nfor an athlete to begin exercise in a hydrated state, drink enough fluid with\nsodium during exercise to maintain body weight within about 2%, and rehydrate\nafter the run using fluid with sodium, in an amount slightly greater than body\nweight loss.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During a marathon run ,\nathletes need to not only consider hydration needs but carbohydrate as well.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Consume a\nhigh-carbohydrate diet, drink plenty of fluid and ensure you consume plenty of\ncalcium and magnesium-rich foods</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Potassium and sodium\nare the electrolytes that help the cells to communicate to one another, through\nelectrical signals. If these electrolytes are out of balance, the messages\nbetween cells lead to involuntary muscle contractions. In some cases, the\nathelete loses the consciousness.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Although rich in\npotassium, coconut water is not a very good source of sodium for marathon\nrunners which is mainly what we are losing in sweat. Drinking coconut water is\ngood\u2014but add some sodium by another drink or food.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Basically every time\nmuscles move, or your heart beats it is electrical impulses that make this\nhappen, each nerve impulse is dependent on an electrical charge, and a number\nof minerals in electrolyte form are vital for these functions to take place,\nthese include Magnesium, Sodium, Potassium and Chloride<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Electrolytes perform\nmany essential functions,&nbsp; working as a\nteam.&nbsp; While they don\u2019t contain energy,\nthey do activate electrical impulses.&nbsp; Muscle\ncontraction requires the presence of adequate sodium, potassium and calcium;\nand muscle weakness and cramping can result when these electrolytes are not\navailable in sufficient quantities<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sodium and chloride are\nthe most abundant, and daily profuse sweating can result in substantial loss of\nthese minerals, which will require supplementation. The runner sweats lower\namounts of potassium, calcium and magnesium.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Muscles need sufficient\nelectrolytes\u2013sodium, magnesium, potassium and chloride\u2014in proper balance to\nfunction properly. The body manipulates the balance of these minerals inside\nand outside of muscle cells in order to get the muscles to contract and relax.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">An imbalance or deficiency of these electrolytes can cause problems with the\nbody\u2019s electrical impulses and lead to muscle cramps and/or muscle spasms. Low\nlevels of any of these minerals can allow the muscle to contract, but prevent\nit from relaxing.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Magnesium, is an\nessential mineral involved in muscle function that helps muscles to contract\nand relax.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sodium (Na) is the\npredominant cation (positively charged element) found in extracellular fluid.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sodium teams with\npotassium, the chief cation of intracellular fluid, to maintain proper body\nfluid and acid-base balance in the cells and tissue and maintain blood\npressure.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Potassium and other electrolytes\u2014such as magnesium and\nchloride\u2014perform numerous, multifaceted roles in the body.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They work in concert\nwith sodium to regulate acid-base, electrolyte, and water balance; conduct\nnerve impulses; promote normal muscle contraction (including the heartbeat);\nregulate the transfer of nutrients to cells; and maintain the normal function\nof the kidneys, heart, and nerve cells.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">An imbalance of any electrolyte can\nhave far-reaching, serious effects within the body.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Their ionic nature\ngives the electrolytes the ability to carry electrical energy to keep the\nbody\u2019s systems functioning.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For a runner, keeping\nyour electrolytes balanced is key for successful training and optimum\nperformance. If your electrolytes are imbalanced, you could potentially\ncompromise the success of your next run because of muscle fatigue or cramping.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Without sufficient\npotassium, your muscles cells can\u2019t generate the necessary nerve impulses that\ncontrol muscle contraction.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cramping is the body\u2019s\nway of letting you know the electrolyte tank is empty and it cannot continue;\nit\u2019s like a car running out of gas.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If you are trying to\nrehydrate by drinking a lot of water, failing to consume electrolytes at the\nsame time can upset the balance of electrolytes in your bloodstream.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When glycogen breaks\ndown to supply energy for workouts, muscle cells are depleted of potassium.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As\na result, there is a greater concentration of potassium in blood and greater\nquantities are lost in the urine. Symptoms of potassium depletion include\nnausea, slower reflexes, irregular heartbeat, drowsiness, and muscle fatigue\nand weakness.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Replenishing lost potassium after exercise is important, but\nhyperkalemia (high serum potassium levels) can cause electrical impulse\ndisturbance, irregular heart beat, and possibly death.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Potassium is extremely\nimportant for the maintenance of water balance and distribution, acid-base\nbalance, muscle and nerve cell function, heart function, kidney and adrenal\nfunction. In addition to functioning as an electrolyte, potassium is essential\nfor conversion of blood sugar into glycogen, the storage form of blood sugar in\nthe muscles and liver.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A potassium shortage results in lower levels of stored\nglycogen. Because exercising muscles use glycogen for energy, a potassium\ndeficiency produces great fatigue and muscle weakness, the first signs of\npotassium deficiency.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The average athlete loses approximately 150 mg of\nPotassium in each liter of sweat .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Exceeding your aerobic\ncapacity -- running too far or too hard ( like TINTU LUKA ) -- leads to\nanaerobic metabolism. This process causes increases in several substances that\ntire muscles and sabotage performance. Concentrations of hydrogen and potassium\nions rise as do levels of inorganic phosphate and adenosine diphosphate, both\nof which break down ATP.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As a result,\nATP production falls and calcium release -- which is necessary for muscle\ncontraction -- is inhibited. Lactic acid builds up as a byproduct of anaerobic\nrespiration. Muscle strength declines and your overall speed slows.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbs are stored in\nyour muscles as glycogen, which your body taps into during workout. To fuel\nyour body and run, reach for complex carbs like whole fruits and vegetables,\ndairy, whole grain, potatoes, legumes. These foods provides host of nutrients,\nincluding fibers, vitamin c and calcium that will help runner perform their\nbest.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Calcium is needed by\nmany other cells to perform different functions in the body: contraction and\nrelaxation of muscle, nerve conduction, secretion of hormones, enzymatic\nreactions, and blood coagulation. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Calcium plays a central\nrole in both the synthesis and breakdown of muscle glycogen and liver glycogen.\nBlood calcium levels are tightly regulated by hormones at the expense of bones.\nMany do not realize that bones are constantly being broken down and rebuilt\nthrough the processes of resorption and formation.. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dairy products like A2\nmilk, cheese and yogurt are excellent sources of dietary calcium. Low serum\nlevels of calcium can cause a number of problems, including muscular cramping\ndue to an imbalance of calcium in the muscle and surrounding fluids. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Muscular contraction\nand exercise performance in active individuals is also compromised by low serum\ncalcium. In addition to calcium intake, athletes should be aware that\nweight-bearing exercise is beneficial in the maintenance of a healthy skeleton.\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Non-weight bearing\nsports like bicycling and swimming have been associated with bone mass similar\nto or below that of normal sedentary people (It is important to fit in some\nweight bearing exercise and consume varied sources of calcium in your diet.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When it comes to\ncontrolling muscle contraction and relaxation, calcium and magnesium are two\nimportant minerals, working synergistically to maintain normal electrical\npotentials and to coordinate muscle contraction relaxation responses in the\nmuscles.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In muscle cells, an increased calcium concentration triggers\ncontraction of the muscle fibres while increased intracellular magnesium concentration\ncounteracts this effect, resulting in relaxation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Calcium plays an\nintegral role in the formation of bones and teeth, which is its main function.\nIt carries nerve impulses, and also aids in muscle contraction and blood\nclotting. Most of the calcium in the body lies within the skeletal system, but\nthe cells and blood need a certain quantity as well. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Calcium needs to be\ningested via external sources so that it is not extracted from the bones,\neventually leading to severe depletion.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Calcium builds bone\nstrength, helps in normal muscle and nerve functioning and water transport\nacross cell membrane deficiencies in calcium spent during extreme exercise may\nfurther trigger imbalances in its ideal ratio of 2:1 to magnesium associated\nwith muscle spasms and cramping.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When we want to\nvoluntarily move, the brain sends an impulse down the spinal cord out the\nperipheral nerve to the muscle cells.&nbsp;\nThis impulse causes calcium (stored in the sarcoplasmic reticulum) to\nflood the muscle filaments (within the cell).&nbsp;\nThis starts a chain of events within the cell resulting in muscle fiber\nshortening, muscle contraction.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In order\nfor the cell to \u201crelax\u201d, the calcium must be returned to the sarcoplasmic\nreticulum and the mitochondria must supply fresh ATP.&nbsp; This process is repeated many times in one\n\u201ccontraction\u201d.&nbsp; The total number of cells\nactivated in a contraction determines how powerful the muscle contracts.&nbsp; From the runner\u2019s standpoint, the rate that\nthis process takes place determines the speed that an athlete can run.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">With this in mind, we can speculate that some\nmuscle cramping can result from a failure to reabsorb calcium, failure to\ndeliver ATP or from excessive, non-voluntary, neural stimulation.&nbsp; The later being the likely cause of running\nrelated muscle cramps.&nbsp; Other causes\ninclude electrolyte imbalances and dehydration.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Magnesium plays a vital\nrole in energy production and your cells need magnesium to be present in order\nto convert glycogen into glucose for energy.&nbsp;\nIt stands to reason, therefore that magnesium deficiency can be\nresponsible for a lack of energy delivery to the working muscle.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Alongside the\nrole in assisting sleep, a key contributor to running performance, magnesium\nalso assists protein synthesis which is vital post run to ensure optimal muscle\nrecovery and therefore reduce muscle soreness on subsequent training efforts,\nparticularly if running on consecutive days. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One of the most\nabundantly present minerals in the body, half of it can be found in bones,\nwhile the rest is found inside the cells of organs and tissues. It facilitates\nseveral important biochemical reactions in the body.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Main functions comprise\nregulation of heart beat, enhanced health of the immune system, facilitating\nnerve &amp; muscle function, controlling blood sugar content, keeping blood\npressure at normal levels and increasing bone strength.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It plays a vital role\nin energy metabolism too. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Magnesium maintains\nmuscle and nerve functions as well as conduction of nerve impulses&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Magnesium is essential\nfor all energy conversion, muscle function, nerve conduction, and more than 300\ndifferent enzymatic reactions, and it is depleted from the body under times of\nphysical and emotional stress.</span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>Chloride </b></span></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">is a most\nabundant negatively charged electrolyte, essential for oxygen exchange,\ndigestion, water and pH balance. Chloride is an electrolyte that helps your\nbody regulate the level of fluids in your body<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Electrolytes are also\nessential to the proper functioning of fluids in the body, which not only act\nas the body\u2019s electrical system, but also as the cooling system and highway,\ndelivering nutrients in and wastes out. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Electrolytes are charged,\nwater-soluble, essential minerals that make the body\u2019s fluids electrically\nconductive. They govern a number of functions in the body including energy\nusage, regulating fluid balance and proper muscle function and are also\nessential to hydration.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Without electrolytes,\nthe body cannot convert dormant energy into active energy.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The energy in a battery\nis created by the movement of charged ions, i.e., electrolytes, and the body\nuses the same process. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">is essential for oxygen exchange, digestion,\nwater and pH balance.</span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dextrose anhydrous is\nthe purest form of dextrose, commonly called glucose. It is manufactured by\nrefining dextrose monohydrate, itself a pure form of dextrose. Dextrose\nanhydrous provides instant energy. It is the primary ingredient in oral\nrehydration salts (ORS).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dextrose anhydrous is used in intravenous (IV) fluids\nto provide nutrients to patients under intensive care who are unable to receive\nthem by the oral route. Dextrose anhydrous complements the function of saline\nsolution for a total electrolyte-energy balance. When dissolved in fluid, salts\ntend to break apart into their component ions, creating an\nelectrically-conductive solution.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For example, table salt (NaCl) dissolved in\nwater dissociates into its component positive ion of sodium (Na+) and negative\nion of chloride (Cl-).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The major\nnegatively-charged ion (anion), chloride is primarily found in extracellular\nfluid and works closely with sodium to maintain proper balance and pressure of\nthe various fluid compartments of the body (blood, inside cells, and the fluid\nbetween cells). It is also vitally important for maintaining proper acidity in\nthe body, passively balancing out the positive ions of blood, tissue and\norgans.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Like sodium, most\nchloride is obtained through salt in the diet.&nbsp;\nChloride toxicity (hyperchloremia) and deficiency (hypochloremia) are\nboth rarities, but can occur due to other electrolyte imbalances. Symptoms may\ninclude respiratory difficulty and pH imbalance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Like sodium, chloride\ninfluences neural activity and muscle function, but chloride carries a negative\ncharge rather than a positive one. Chloride is primarily found along with\nsodium in ordinary table salt, otherwise known as sodium chloride, and because\nit is in most foods, insufficient intake is rare. Chloride, in the form of\nhydrochloric acid, is also a major component of gastric juice, which in turn\ndigests and absorbs essential nutrients from food.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride is an \u201cessential\u201d\nmineral for humans.&nbsp; It is abundant in\nionic trace mineral preparations. It is a major mineral nutrient that occurs\nprimarily in body fluids. Chloride is a prominent negatively charged ion of the\nblood, where it represents 70% of the body\u2019s total negative ion content.&nbsp; On average, an adult human body contains\napproximately 115 grams of chloride, making up about 0.15% of total body\nweight.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The suggested amount of chloride intake ranges from 750 to 900\nmilligrams per day, based on the fact that total obligatory loss of chloride in\nthe average person is close to 530 milligrams per day.&nbsp; As the principle negatively charged ion in\nthe body, chloride serves as one of the main electrolytes of the body.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride, in addition to potassium and sodium, assist in the conduction of\nelectrical impulses when dissolved in bodily water. Potassium and sodium become\npositive ions as they lose an electron when dissolved and chloride becomes a\nnegative ion as it gains an electron when dissolved. A positive ion is always\naccompanied by a negative ion, hence the close relationship between sodium,\npotassium and chloride.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The electrolytes are distributed throughout all body\nfluids including the blood, lymph, and the fluid inside and outside cells. The\nnegative charge of chloride balances against the positive charges of sodium and\npotassium ions in order to maintain serum osmolarity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In addition to its\nfunctions as an electrolyte, chloride combines with hydrogen in the stomach to\nmake hydrochloric acid, a powerful digestive enzyme that is responsible for the\nbreak down of proteins, absorption of other metallic minerals, and activation of\nintrinsic factor, which in turn absorbs vitamin B12.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride is specially\ntransported into the gastric lumen, in exchange for another negatively charged\nelectrolyte (bicarbonate), in order to maintain electrical neutrality across\nthe stomach membrane. After utilization in hydrochloric acid, some chloride is\nreabsorbed by the intestine, back into the blood stream where it is required\nfor maintenance of extracellular fluid volume.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride is both actively and\npassively absorbed by the body, depending on the current metabolic\ndemands.&nbsp; A constant exchange of chloride\nand bicarbonate, between red blood cells and the plasma helps to govern the pH\nbalance and transport of carbon dioxide, a waste product of respiration, from\nthe body.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">With sodium and potassium, chloride works in the nervous system to\naid in the transport of electrical impulses throughout the body, as movement of\nnegatively charged chloride into the cell propagates the nervous electrical\npotential.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Deficiency of chloride\nis rare.&nbsp; However, when it does occur, it\nresults in a life threatening condition known as alkalosis, in which the blood\nbecomes overly alkaline. A tedious balance between alkalinity and acidity is in\nconstant flux, and must be vigilantly maintained throughout the entire body.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Alkalosis\nmay occur as a result of excessive loss of sodium, such as heavy sweating\nduring endurance exercise, and in cases of prolonged vomiting and diarrhea.\nSymptoms include muscle weakness, loss of appetite, irritability, dehydration,\nand profound lethargy.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hypochloremia may result from water overload, wasting\nconditions, and extensive bodily burns with sequestration of extracellular\nfluids. In a situation in which infants were inadvertently fed\nchloride-deficient formula, many experienced failure to thrive, anorexia, and\nweakness in their first year of life.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Excessive intakes of\ndietary chloride only occur with the ingestion of large amounts of salt and\npotassium chloride. The toxic effects of such diets, such as fluid retention\nand high blood pressure, are attributed to the high sodium and potassium\nlevels.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride toxicity has not been\nobserved in humans except in the special case of impaired sodium chloride\nmetabolism, e.g. in congestive heart failure. Healthy individuals can tolerate\nthe intake of large quantities of chloride provided that there is a concomitant\nintake of fresh water.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Other situations in which increased blood levels of\nchloride are seen include diseases of improper waste elimination that occur in\nkidney diseases. Excess chloride is normally excreted in the urine, sweat, and\nbowels. In fact, excess urinary excretion of chloride occurs in high salt\ndiets.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Excessive intakes of chloride can occur in a person with compromised\nhealth in addition to an unhealthy diet.&nbsp;\nHowever, those that follow a healthy diet and lead an active lifestyle\nmay need to consider supplementing their diet with this important mineral.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mineral supplement\nchloride is very different from the gas chlorine.&nbsp; While elemental chlorine is a dangerous gas\nthat does not exist in the free elemental state in nature because of its\nreactivity, although it is widely distributed in combination with other\nelements.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride is related to chlorine however, as one of the most common\nchlorine compounds is common salt, NaCl. &nbsp;&nbsp;Chloride is a by-product of the reaction\nbetween chlorine and an electrolyte, such as potassium, magnesium, or sodium,\nwhich are essential for human metabolism.&nbsp;\nChloride salts are essential for sustaining human metabolism and have\nnone of the effects of isolated chlorine gas. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride occurs\nnaturally in foods at levels normally less than 0.36 milligrams per gram of\nfood. The average intake of chloride during a salt-free diet is approximately\n100 milligrams per day. Unfortunately, chloride is found commonly combined with\nundesirable dietary sources.&nbsp; The most\ncommon of these negative sources is table salt.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Table salt is made from a combination of sodium and chloride ions. Other\nunhealthful sources include yeast extracts, processed lunchmeats, and cheeses.\nHealthier sources of chloride include ionic trace minerals, olives, rye,\ntomatoes, lettuce, and celery, although not in large enough amounts to supply\nthe needs of an active adult. In its original form, however, chloride is\nleached from various rocks into soil and water by years of weathering\nprocesses. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Without chloride, the\nhuman body would be unable to maintain fluids in blood vessels, conduct nerve\ntransmissions, move muscles, or maintain proper kidney function.&nbsp; As a major electrolyte mineral of the body,\nchloride performs many roles, and is rapidly excreted from the body. Active\nadults that eat a healthy diet devoid of salt and illnesses in which vomiting\nand/or diarrhea are profuse warrant the supplementation of additional\nchloride.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">eplacement of chloride is essential\non a daily basis to maintain regular metabolic function.&nbsp; Chloride is safely utilized by the body,\nwithout negative health effects.&nbsp; Of the\nnegative health effects that have been associated with diets high in chloride,\nthese are mainly attributable to the accompanying sodium and potassium, two\nother electrolyte minerals to which chloride is often attached<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The human body is\nprimarily made up of water and cells that need to constantly receive nutrients\nin order to sustain life. Minerals that are found in the body and transport\nnecessary nutrients as well as a positive or negative charge are referred to as\nelectrolytes. Chloride is an electrolyte mineral that dissolves in water and\ncarries a negative charge. Because Chloride dissolves in water, it is found\naround each and every cell in the human body. Chloride moves easily through\ncell membranes and delivers nutrients, than removes excess waste upon exiting.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride plays a major\nrole in balancing body cells as well as digestion. As a dietary element,\nchloride works well alongside potassium and sodium, both of which have positive\ncharges and compliment chloride\u2019s negative charge. The combination of these\nthree electrolytes helps deliver needed nutrients to cells throughout the body\nand aides in balancing the water levels surrounding cells as well which is\nimportant for their proper functioning.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride helps in\nmaintaining proper kidney function and assists in keeping fluid flow through\ntissues and blood vessels efficient. Just as importantly, chloride is a necessary\ningredient in the body\u2019s creation of hydrochloric acid which is used to digest\nfood in the stomach.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride (Cl-) forms\nwhen chlorine (Cl2) reacts with hydrogen or sodium. Whereas chlorine is a\npoisonous gas, chloride is an essential mineral and the most abundant anion in\nyour extracellular fluid: fluids such as blood which bathe cellular tissue.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The total amount of\nchloride within your body represents about 0.15% of your body weight which is\nabout 105 g for a 70 kg person. Approximately 12% of this amount is found\nwithin your cells, but the bulk of chloride (88%) is within you extracellular\nfluid.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Anions such as Cl- have\na negative charge and are commonly associated with positively charged cations\nsuch as sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+). The amount of chloride within your\nbody is about the same as the amount of sodium with which it is commonly\nassociated.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chloride is one of\nseveral electrolytes in your body and with sodium and potassium is necessary\nfor maintaining your body\u2019s homeostasis. As an electrolyte, chloride assists\nwith fluid balance, delivery of oxygen to your cells, and acid-base balance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In your extracellular\nfluid, chloride which can move easily across cell membranes associates with\nsodium, but within your cells associates with potassium. Together, electrolytes\nmaintain a voltage across cell membranes which functions to carry other\nnutrients in and out of cells.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Electrolytes are\nparticularly important in muscle, nerve and heart cells where they act together\nto conduct electrical impulses for nerve impulses and muscle contractions. Your\nkidneys maintain consistent blood electrolyte concentrations.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The term \u201celectrolytes\u201d\nrefers to salts, such as sodium chloride and potassium chloride which dissolve\nin water and separate into charged ions: Sodium = Na+, Chloride = Cl-, and\nPotassium = K+. Water containing dissolved electrolytes can conduct an\nelectrical current and is known as an electrolyte solution.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The negative and\npositive charges are matched so that if more negative ions come into the\nsolution negative ions must leave or positive ions must enter the solution to\nequalise the negative ions. That is, if Na+ ions come into the solution K+ ions\nmust leave. Sodium and potassium usually move in opposite directions across\ncell membranes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sodium and chloride are\ngenerally found outside of body cells while potassium, magnesium, sulfate and\nphosphorus are found within cells.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Our bodies rely on a\nsophisticated buffering system to maintain proper pH levels. Lungs regulate the\namount of carbon dioxide in the body, most of which is combined with water and\nconverted to carbonic acid (H2CO3). This carbonic acid can then be quickly\nconverted to bicarbonate (HCO3-), which is the key component in the pH buffer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When acids build up\nthrough metabolic processes or production of lactic acid in your muscles, the\nkidneys release this bicarbonate (an alkaline solution) into your system to\ncounteract the increased acidity. If your body is becoming more basic, the\nkidneys will lessen the amount of bicarbonate to increase acidity. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Without this system,\nrapid changes in pH balance could cause severe problems in the body like\ndamaging sensitive tissue around the central nervous system. This bicarbonate\nbuffer is one of the biggest reason our bodies can maintain homeostasis and\nfunction properly.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 150%;\"><b>ATP, Adenosine\nTriphosphate</b></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"> is&nbsp; the chemical in the\nmuscle cell that is broken down and in conjunction with sugars, actually\nproduces energy. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Prolonged exercise\nrequires sustained energy to maintain muscle contraction. This energy is\nprovided by the continual production of ATP (adenosine triphosphate), the\nuniversal energy molecule.&nbsp;&nbsp; ATP is\nproduced when a fuel is broken down to release energy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nutrition or energy is\nretained from converting carbohydrates, fat, and protein to adenosine\ntriphosphate or ATP.&nbsp;&nbsp; When ATP is broken\ndown energy is released which allows the muscles to contract.&nbsp;&nbsp; Different nutrients have their unique\nproperties which determine how they get converted to ATP.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is not easy for our\nbody to store ATP (whatever stored ATP there is would be used up in a matter of\nseconds), so it is critical to continuously create ATP during exercise. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For any training of\nmoderate to high intensity carbohydrate is the main source of energy. Low\nintensity exercise for longer periods of time uses fat as its main source of\nenergy. Body tissue and especially the damaged muscles are repaired by proteins\nwhich are normally not used as fuel for muscle activity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Aerobic metabolism\n(with oxygen)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Anaerobic metabolism\n(without oxygen)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">If aerobic metabolism is\nBrahma , anaerobic metabolism is Shiva\u2014 mediated by Vishnu. &nbsp;&nbsp;Hindu&nbsp;\nTRINITY gods are cosmic forces at the macro and micro level. &nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-N8h9JFGqvoY/V9yryzCxtoI/AAAAAAABL60/v5kJIDPrIUcd91Y3_zipdvIBbSsKuCBBQCLcB/s1600/trimurtEEhi1.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"350\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-N8h9JFGqvoY/V9yryzCxtoI/AAAAAAABL60/v5kJIDPrIUcd91Y3_zipdvIBbSsKuCBBQCLcB/s640/trimurtEEhi1.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>The trinity works as a team, they do NOT hold\ncompetitions or upstage each other or screw each other\u2019s wives behind their backs\nor eat corpses or commit incest or have anal sex and produce avatars --&nbsp;</b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; I shall take care of their legacy.&nbsp;</b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Below: ATP was&nbsp;</span><span style=\"line-height: 24px;\">discovered</span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;by an Indian Yellapragada &nbsp;-- he was deprived of the Nobel prize by his JEW boss Fiske.</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; line-height: 150%; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/lO1oXQ3eS_s/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/lO1oXQ3eS_s?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/08/yellapragada-subbarow-nobel-prize-and.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/08/yellapragada-subbarow-nobel-prize-and.html</a><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><b>TREHAN BABY-- IN THE VIDEO BELOW TATTU BRAHMACHARI SHAKTI HAI KYA ?&nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><b>BOLOH TOH BAAP KEE PEEPTA ?</b></span><br />\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; line-height: 150%; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/vhtJMxAt0KU/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/vhtJMxAt0KU?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/b1gEvZzqyxE/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/b1gEvZzqyxE?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ATP-CP (adenosine\ntriphosphate - creatine phosphate) is an energy pathway that supplies about 8\nto 10 seconds of energy for short extremely high running bursts such as a 100\nmeter sprint by Usain Bolt. &nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This anaerobic energy\npathway doesn't need any oxygen to create the ATP. &nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">First all the ATP is\nstored in the muscle is used up after that the creatine phosphate is used to\nre-synthesize ATP until there is no more CP. After this process the body will\nchange its energy supply to either aerobic or anaerobic metabolism (energy from\nglycogen) to produce ATP to fuel exercise.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; line-height: 150%; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/EkjR04SHuV0/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/EkjR04SHuV0?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; line-height: 150%; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot;
